Comment: I would expect the tariff to be based on the wholesale price of the item. However, as sales decline because people don't buy as much, the goods that are sold have to be sold at a high enough price to allow the retailer to maintain their usual profit.  This means that sales ALSO must pay a higher share of fixed costs.  Consider a store that buys items for $5, sells them at $10, and has to pay a 100% tariff based n the wholesale price of $5 ,Presume that demand is elastiic, meaning that as price goes up 10%, the amount sold will decline by some precentage. Suppose that normal sales are 10,000 units per month for income of $100,000. At $15, the store can expect to sell roughly 6667 for revenue of $100,000, but they will need to pay tariff on all items ordered. To keep income the same, the item has to be marked up to $18-20..  Another consequence of the tariffs is that order size will get smaller for at least two resons: tariff has to be paid at the port of entry and recovered from customers as the items are sold, and there is a risk that the tariffs will be redced or eliminated at some future date. amd companies don't want to be stuck with goods where they ad to pay atariff tat no longer applies.
